docs.lead_paragraph: The American Nurses Association and others respond to an Op-Ed article about nurse-patient ratios.
docs.snippet: The American Nurses Association and others respond to an Op-Ed article about nurse-patient ratios.

docs.lead_paragraph: Many insurers say they are asking for higher premiums because they remain unsure about the future and what their medical costs will be.

headline.main: Seeking Rate Increases, Insurers Use Guesswork

docs.abstract: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services data shows for the 37 states using HealthCare.gov as their exchange, insurance companies are seeking very different rate increases, some as high as 85 percent, for premiums in 2016; officials caution final rates still have yet to be set and experts warn that data is not sure predictor of prices; proposed rate increases are due to insurers uncertainty.
docs.snippet: Many insurers say they are asking for higher premiums because they remain unsure about the future and what their medical costs will be.

docs.lead_paragraph: Corizon, a for-profit company, has been accused by state investigators of neglecting and improperly treating inmates at the jail complex, a dozen of whom have died.

headline.main: Rikers Island Health Care Provider May Lose Deal With New York
headline.print_headline: Health Care Company May Lose Rikers Deal

docs.abstract: Corizon, for-profit heath care company that has been accused of neglecting and improperly treating inmates at Rikers Island jail complex, will reportedly lose its contract with New York City.
docs.snippet: Corizon, a for-profit company, has been accused by state investigators of neglecting and improperly treating inmates at the jail complex, a dozen of whom have died.

docs.lead_paragraph: Readers respond to articles in Science Times.
docs.snippet: Readers respond to articles in Science Times.

docs.lead_paragraph: Data from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services include payments and services connected with the 100 most common Medicare hospital stays.

headline.main: Data Shows Large Rise in List Prices at Hospitals
headline.print_headline: Data Shows Large Rise in List Prices at Hospitals

docs.abstract: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services data shows that prices charged by hospitals for variety of common procedures has increased over 10 percent from 2011 to 2013, while amounts paid by Medicare has not changed; rising prices are of most concern to those who are uninsured or those who are treated in hospitals not within their coverage network.
docs.snippet: Data from the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services include payments and services connected with the 100 most common Medicare hospital stays.

byline.contributor: Griffin Palmer, Sarah Cohen and Reed Abelson contributed reporting.
byline.original: By MARGOT SANGER-KATZ and KATIE THOMAS

docs.lead_paragraph: Dozens of health insurers say higher-than-expected care costs and other expenses blindsided them this year, and they're going to have to hike premiums for individual policies well-beyond 10 percent for 2016.

headline.main: Many Health Insurers Go Big With Initial 2016 Rate Requests
headline.print_headline: Many Health Insurers Go Big With Initial 2016 Rate Requests

docs.snippet: Dozens of health insurers say higher-than-expected care costs and other expenses blindsided them this year, and they're going to have to hike premiums for individual policies well-beyond 10 percent for 2016.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama is not shy about defining his achievements and casting them in the most positive light, yet he is loath to talk about his "legacy."

docs.lead_paragraph: Joint replacement was the most common hospital procedure that Medicare paid for in 2013, accounting for nearly 450,000 inpatient admissions and $6.6 billion in payments.

docs.lead_paragraph: Medicare, the government-run health insurance program for elderly and disabled Americans, paid physicians $90 billion in 2013, up 17 percent from $77 billion in 2012, U.S. healthcare officials reported on Monday.

headline.main: Medicare Paid Doctors $90 Billion in 2013, Up 17 Percent: Officials
headline.print_headline: Medicare Paid Doctors $90 Billion in 2013, Up 17 Percent: Officials

docs.snippet: Medicare, the government-run health insurance program for elderly and disabled Americans, paid physicians $90 billion in 2013, up 17 percent from $77 billion in 2012, U.S. healthcare officials reported on Monday.

docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday ruled in favor of a Muslim woman who sued for discrimination after being denied a sales job at age 17 at an Abercrombie & Fitch Co clothing store in Oklahoma because she wore a head scarf for religious reasons.

headline.main: U.S. Top Court Backs Muslim Woman Denied Job Over Head Scarf
headline.print_headline: U.S. Top Court Backs Muslim Woman Denied Job Over Head Scarf

docs.snippet: The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday ruled in favor of a Muslim woman who sued for discrimination after being denied a sales job at age 17 at an Abercrombie & Fitch Co clothing store in Oklahoma because she wore a head scarf for religious reasons.
